abstract.text: A control for the inputting of date and time values.
The mode of the date picker.
The date displayed by the date picker.
The minimum date that a date picker can show.
The maximum date that a date picker can show.
The interval at which the date picker should display minutes.
The value displayed by the date picker when the mode property is set to show a countdown time.

The base class for controls, which are visual elements that convey a specific action or intention in response to user interactions.
The current style of the date picker.

A control for the inputting of date and time values.
The preferred style of the date picker.
Styles that determine the appearance of a date picker.
The calendar to use for the date picker.
Sets the date to display in the date picker, with an option to animate the setting.
The time zone reflected in the date displayed by the date picker.
The mode displayed by the date picker.
A control that executes your custom code in response to user interactions.
A control that displays a color picker.
A control that displays a horizontal series of dots, each of which corresponds to a page in the app’s document or other data-model entity.
A horizontal control that consists of multiple segments, each segment functioning as a discrete button.
A control for selecting a single value from a continuous range of values.
A control for incrementing or decrementing a value.
A control that offers a binary choice, such as on/off.

inlineContent.text: You can use a date picker to allow a user to enter either a point in time (calendar date, time value, or both) or a time interval (for example, for a timer). The date picker reports interactions to its associated target object.
To add a date picker to your interface:
Set the date picker mode at creation time.
Supply additional configuration options such as minimum and maximum dates if required.
Connect an action method to the date picker.
Set up Auto Layout rules to govern the position of the date picker in your interface.
You use a date picker only for handling the selection of times and dates. If you want to handle the selection of arbitrary items from a list, use a
object.
The
property determines the configuration of a date picker. You can set the

value programmatically or in Interface Builder. For modes that include date or time values, you can also configure the locale, calendar, and time zone information. The date picker uses that information when formatting date and time values for the current user, and defaults to the device’s locale, calendar, and time zone. The
property represents the currently selected date in the form of an
object, which is calendar and time zone agnostic.
To limit the range of dates that the user can select, assign values to the
and
properties. You can also use the
property to allow only specific time increments.
Setting the
property to
allows the user to choose a duration in hours and minutes. When in this mode, the
property represents the displayed duration, measured in seconds as an
. Note that even though you set this property in seconds, the date picker can only show values in minutes.

property set to

You can use a
object for the selection of a time interval, but you must use an
object to implement the actual timer behavior. For more information, see
Date pickers use the
design pattern to notify your app when the user changes the selected date. To be notified when the date picker’s value changes, register your action method with the
event. At runtime the date picker calls your methods in response to the user selecting a date or time.
You connect a date picker to your action method using the
method or by creating a connection in Interface Builder. The signature of an action method takes one of three forms, which are listed in
. Choose the form that provides the information that you need to respond to the value change in the date picker.

abstract.text: Action methods for date pickers

inlineContent.text: When debugging issues with date pickers, watch for these common pitfalls:
The minimum date must be earlier than the maximum date.
Check the bounds of your
and

properties. If the maximum date is less than the minimum date, both properties are ignored, and the date picker allows the selection of any date value. The minimum and maximum dates are ignored in the countdown-timer mode (
The minute interval must be a divisor of 60.
Check that the
value can be evenly divided into 60; otherwise, the default value is used (
lists the core attributes that you configure for date pickers in Attributes Inspector within Interface Builder.
Attribute
Description
Style
The date picker style. Determines the appearance of the date picker. Access this value at runtime with the
property.
Mode
The date picker mode. Determines whether the date picker should display a time, a date, a time and date, or a countdown interval. Access this value at runtime with the
property.
Locale
The locale associated with the date picker. This property allows you to override the system default with a specific locale. You can access this attribute programmatically with the
property.
Interval

The granularity of the minutes spinner, if it is shown in the current mode. The default value is 1, and the maximum value is 30. The value you choose must be a divisor of 60 (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 10, 12, 15, 20, 30). Access this value at runtime with the
property.

abstract.text: Core attributes

inlineContent.text: lists the attributes that control the display of date and time in a date picker.
Attribute
Description
Date
The initial date that the date picker will display. Defaults to the current date, but you can set a custom value. This attribute is equivalent to setting the
property programmatically.
Constraints
The range of selectable dates displayed by the date picker. To use a dynamic range, configure the
and
properties programmatically. The date picker ignores these options when the Mode attribute is set to Count Down Timer.
Timer
The initial value of the date picker when used in countdown timer mode. The value is measured in seconds, but the display is in minutes.

abstract.text: Time attributes

inlineContent.text: For information about the date picker’s inherited Interface Builder attributes, see

You can change the appearance of
by setting
. For a list of appearance styles, see
You should integrate date pickers in your layout using Auto Layout. Although date pickers can be resized, they should be used at their intrinsic content size.

Date pickers handle their own internationalization; the only thing you need to do is specify the appropriate locale. You can choose a specific locale for your date picker to appear in by setting the Locale (

) field in Attributes Inspector. Setting the locale changes the language that the date picker uses for display, but also the format of the date and time (for example, certain locales present days before month names, or prefer a 24-hour clock over a 12-hour clock). The width of the date picker automatically accommodates for the length of the localization. To use the system language, leave this property set to default.
For more information, see
Date pickers are accessible by default. Each time component in the date picker is its own accessibility element and has the Adjustable (
) trait.

The device reads the accessibility value, traits, and hint out loud for each date picker when the user enables VoiceOver. VoiceOver speaks this information when a user taps on a picker wheel. For example, when a user taps the hours column on the Add Alarm page (Clock > Alarm > Add), VoiceOver speaks the following:

code: "2 o'clock. Picker item. Adjustable. Swipe up or down with one finger to adjust the value.__"__
